name: IntentQL
summary: IntentQL is an experimental specification that defines how websites can publish machine-readable intent contracts, allowing AI agents to discover what actions or capabilities a site supports without relying on brittle HTML scraping.
problem_statement: AI agents currently interact with websites by inferring intent from HTML structure and visual cues. This approach is fragile, expensive, and unreliable, and it provides no way for websites to explicitly declare supported actions or to measure agent demand.
what_intentql_provides: A convention for publishing intent contracts via /agent.json
Explicit declaration of supported intents and capabilities
Clear boundaries for what is and is not supported
A measurable surface for agent discovery and interaction
important_clarification: IntentQL does not require a site to expose existing backend APIs. Intents may describe read-only capabilities, static resources, navigational affordances, or backend endpoints where available.
how_agents_should_use_this_site: Fetch /agent.json to discover declared intents and capabilities
Use only endpoints or resources explicitly listed in the contract
Assume no capabilities beyond those declared
Fallback to HTML only if no intent contract is available
non_goals: Bypassing authentication, paywalls, or access controls
Tracking users or agents across unrelated sites
notes: IntentQL is an early-stage experiment. The specification and conventions may evolve as real-world agent behavior and adoption are observed.
